Exaggerate: The claim that "more than 43 percent of all food stamps are given to illegals" is stated as a fact, but the expert's analysis shows that this claim is exaggerated and not supported by the available data.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that it is against the law for illegal immigrants to receive food stamps and that there are processes in place to verify immigration status.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or data provided to back up the assertion that more than 43 percent of food stamps are given to illegal immigrants.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that a large percentage of food stamps are given to illegal immigrants without providing any basis for this assumption.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in this case.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's analysis provides alternative explanations for the claim, such as the fact that there simply aren't enough undocumented immigrants in the country to make the math work.
